metadata.titleEn: Geochemical dataset of Late Cretaceous magmatic rocks from Baingoin in central Tibet
metadata.description: The dataset includes whole-rock major and trace elemental, zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic data. Samples were collected from dacites and rhyolites from Baingoin in central Tibet. Zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic data were analyzed on LA-IC-MS and LA-MC-ICP-MS, respectively. Whole-rock major and trace elemental analyses were performed on XRF and ICP-MS, respectively. The data has very good quality. These data are able to constrain the age, genesis, and tectonic settings of post-collisional Late Cretaceous magmatism from northern Lhasa subterrane.
metadata.instructions: All data are Excel files: UPb.xlsx for zircon U-Pb dating data, WRMT.xlsx for whole-rock major and trace elemental data, Hf.xlsx for zircon Hf isotopic data.

literatureList.titleEn: Westward-younging high-Mg adakitic magmatism in central Tibet: Record of a westward-migrating lithospheric foundering beneath the Lhasa–Qiangtang collision zone during the Late Cretaceous
literatureList.referenceEn: Yi, J.K., Wang, Q., Zhu, D.C., Li, S.M., Liu, S.A., Wang, R., Zhang, L.L., & Zhao, Z.D. (2018). Westward-younging high-Mg adakitic magmatism in central Tibet: Record of a westward-migrating lithospheric foundering beneath the Lhasa–Qiangtang collision zone during the Late Cretaceous. Lithos, 316-317, 92-103. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.lithos.2018.07.001

Definition.Question: What is the process of obtaining zircon U-Pb age data using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry?
Definition.Answer: Zircon U-Pb age data is obtained through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, which involves using a focused laser beam to ablate a small area of a zircon crystal. The ablated material is then carried by a carrier gas into the inductively coupled plasma, where it is ionized. The ions are then analyzed by the mass spectrometer to determine the isotopic composition, allowing for the calculation of the U-Pb age of the zircon.

Interpretation.Question: What can the geochemical data of ignimbrite and rhyolitic porphyry rocks reveal about the tectonic evolution and magmatic processes in the post-collisional Late Cretaceous period in central Tibet?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical data of ignimbrite and rhyolitic porphyry rocks, including major and trace elements, zircon U-Pb ages, and Hf isotopic compositions, can provide insights into the timing, genesis, and formation environment of magmatism in the region. By analyzing these data, researchers can infer the tectonic evolution and magmatic processes that occurred during the post-collisional Late Cretaceous period in central Tibet.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the selection of specific geochemical analysis techniques for studying magmatic rocks in central Tibet during the Late Cretaceous?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of geochemical analysis techniques, such as laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U–Pb dating and Hf isotopic analysis, as well as X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for whole-rock major and trace element geochemistry, is driven by the need to obtain reliable data on the age, origin, and formation context of the magmatic activity in the northern Lhasa terrane following the Late Cretaceous collision events.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential implications on data accuracy and geochemical analysis when using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry for collecting zircon U–Pb age and whole-rock geochemical data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry provides reliable data quality for zircon U–Pb age and whole-rock geochemical analysis. This approach allows researchers to accurately determine the age, origin, and formation background of magmatic activities in the specified region, contributing to a deeper understanding of the post-collisional magmatism of the Late Cretaceous period in the northern Lhasa Terrane.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting geochemical data, including zircon U-Pb ages and Hf isotopes, from magmatic rocks in regions like central Tibet's Bangoin area during the Late Cretaceous period?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting geochemical data, including zircon U-Pb ages and Hf isotopes from magmatic rocks in regions like central Tibet's Bangoin area during the Late Cretaceous period, is to determine the timing, origin, and formation background of post-collisional magmatism in the northern Lhasa terrane.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental techniques and procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing zircon U-Pb age and Hf isotope data to understand geological formations in magmatic rocks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Zircon U-Pb age and Hf isotope data are collected using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). This method involves sampling zircon crystals from magmatic rocks, ablating them with a laser to produce an aerosol, and then analyzing the isotopic composition of the aerosol in a mass spectrometer to determine age and isotopic ratios.
